title: Stephen Strasburg, Nationals dominate Cardinals, 1 win from World Series
text:
By the time Stephen Strasburg jogged off the mound at 10:20 p.m. Monday, the Nationals had not only received another gem from a starting pitcher but their ace exited the game with a commanding lead in hand.

Strasburg had done his job. And so too did the rest of the Nationals.

As a result, they are now one win away from the World Series.

Strasburg fanned 12 batters over seven innings and Washington hammered the St. Louis Cardinals in a 8-1 victory to take a 3-0 series lead in the National League Championship Series.

The Nationals used a four-run third inning, while tacking on additional runs in the fifth, sixth and seventh to put the Cardinals on the brink of elimination.

Beyond Strasburg’s dominance, Adam Eaton, Anthony Rendon, Howie Kendrick, Ryan Zimmerman and Victor Robles all batted in runs — creating a bigger cushion than Washington had enjoyed in the first two games of the NLCS.

In St. Louis, the Nationals dominated the Cardinals with elite performances from Anibal Sanchez and Max Scherzer. Each starter carried a no-hitter into at least the seventh inning and both gave up only one hit.

Strasburg, though, didn’t disappoint.

From the moment celebrity announcer Michael Buffer announced “Let’s get ready to rumble” to get Game 3 officially underway, Strasburg was dialed in. The 31-year-old needed just 10 pitches to retire the side to begin the game.

And while the suspense of a no-hitter ended early — Marcell Ozuna doubled to left in the second — it didn’t matter. Strasburg took care of the next three at-bats, including catching Ozuna in a rundown between second and third to record an out.

The Nationals, however, haven’t gotten to this point with only excellent pitching. They’ve been solid in the field, dating back to spring training when manager Dave Martinez stressed the importance of fundamentals. They’ve become a buzzsaw offensively, especially in the playoffs.

And on Monday, Washington’s offensive explosion started in the third.

Eaton got the Nationals on the board with a two-out double to score Robles. The score was the start of a four-run rally, which included RBI doubles from Rendon and Howie Kendrick.

Until then, Cardinals starter Jack Flaherty had previously gone 18 consecutive starts without allowing more than three runs.

St. Louis scored its lone run in the seventh.
